awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Water on the Antarctic Ice Sheet: Quantifying Surface Melt and Mapping Supraglacial Lakes
awd_abstract_narration:
Melting of snow and ice at the surface of the Antarctic ice sheet can lead to the formation of meltwater lakes, an important precursor to ice-shelf collapse and accelerated ice-sheet mass loss. Understanding the present state of Antarctic surface melt provides a baseline to gauge how quickly melt impacts could evolve in the future and to reduce uncertainties in estimates of future sea-level rise. This project will use a suite of complimentary measurements from Earth-observing satellites, ground observations, and numerical climate and ice-shelf models to enhance understanding of surface melt and lakes, as well as the processes linking these systems. The project directly supports the scientific training of a postdoctoral associate and several undergraduate researchers. In addition, it will promote public scientific literacy and the broadening of quantitative skills for high-school students through the development and implementation of an educational unit in a partnership with an education and outreach expert and two high school teachers.

Accurate prediction of sea-level contributions from Antarctica critically requires understanding current melting and supraglacial lake conditions. This project will quantify Antarctic surface melt and supraglacial lakes, and the linkages between the two phenomena.  Scatterometer data will enable generation of a 19-year multi-sensor melt time series. Synthetic aperture radar data will document melt conditions across all Antarctic ice shelves at the highest spatial resolution to date (40 m). Multispectral satellite imagery will be used to delineate and measure the depth of supraglacial lakes--for the first time studying the spatial and temporal variations of Antarctic supraglacial lakes. Melt and lake observations will be compared to identify agreement and disagreement. Melt observations will be used to evaluate biases in a widely used, reanalysis-driven, regional climate model. This model will then be used to examine climatic and glaciological variables associated with supraglacial lakes. Finally, in situ observations and climate model output will drive a numerical model that simulates the entire lifecycle of surface melt and possible subsequent lake formation.

por.por_cntn:
The Antarctic ice sheet’s contributions to global sea level are in part dictated by the health of its floating ice shelves through which much of the ice sheet flows. Surface melt intensity and the accumulation and drainage of surface lakes are factors potentially influencing ice shelf stability. Understanding recent meltwater processes can therefore generate insights into the links between surface hydrological processes and ice shelf stability, thus enabling more informed projections of future ice sheet change. Through close collaboration between researchers at The Pennsylvania State University and the University of Colorado Boulder, this project focused on using satellite observations to improve the understanding of Antarctic surface meltwater.

 

Here, we highlight key outcomes generated at Penn State. First, we identified that surface lake drainages on East Antarctica’s Amery Ice Shelf closely correspond to peaks in the amplitude of ocean tides. This research indicates that tidal-induced flexure inherent to the ice shelf grounding zone, when combined with sufficient surface meltwater volumes, can trigger rapid ice shelf surface lake drainages (Trusel et al., 2022). Given that ice shelf grounding zones are also locations of topographic depressions, we speculate that frequent lake drainages in these regions could limit surface meltwater accumulation despite the enhanced surface meltwater production that is common to these areas. Ongoing research is further exploring this new tidal-induced hydrofracture hypothesis, identifying multiple additional lakes on Amery Ice Shelf that drain in sync with peaks in ocean tides (Fatula and Trusel, in prep.). The second major outcome of this research was quantifying rates of surface meltwater production across the Antarctic Peninsula using a machine learning framework that fuses satellite radar and climate reanalysis data (Pan and Trusel, in prep.). This dataset, ASCAT-ERA5, spans 15 melt seasons (2007-2022) and documents the daily intensity of surface melt at relatively high spatial resolution (4.45 km). Given that satellite measurements typically provide only binary melt presence/absence information, understanding the dynamics of surface meltwater production has traditionally relied on simulating surface melt using climate models. Our new results therefore offer an important, observationally based dataset to investigate the intensity and drivers of surface melting in Antarctica’s highest-melt region, and with which to evaluate climate model outputs.

 

Our research findings have been widely disseminated through scientific conferences and peer-reviewed literature, and they have important implications for understanding surface hydrological variability in Antarctica and its impact on ice shelf stability. The project also contributed to the education and training of three undergraduates and one graduate student, who actively participated in original research and presented their work at conferences and in journal articles. Furthermore, the results were directly incorporated into multiple editions of PI Trusel's Cryosphere and Climate Systems course at Penn State, enriching students' understanding of applied data analysis using Python, polar meteorology, climate modeling, and remote sensing of ice sheet surface water. Code and data products from the project have been made available in openly accessible repositories, ensuring broader access to these resources. Moreover, the project supported the development of an NGSS-aligned high school educational unit focused on Antarctica and climate change, aiming to enhance awareness and understanding of these topics among younger audiences (https://cires.colorado.edu/outreach/programs/antarctica-connecting-climate-change-melting-ice-shelves-and-pooping-penguins).
